My name is James Saryerwinnie. I am a software development engineer

the major features of the CLI, as well as walking through an example

what is the AWS Command Line Interface? It's a relatively new tool.

We just had our 1.0 release this
past September, and it's a unified tool to manage
your AWS services.

And unified is key here. By unified, I mean that you have one tool that has one installation process
and one configuration process,
and access to over two dozen AWS services. Now, it hasn't always been this way.

Historically, each service team has
provided their own CLI. So, you'd have a separate install and configuration process per CLI,

and there might be different prerequisites,
Java or Ruby. And as the number of services grew,
we realized we had the opportunity to consolidate and unify the command land so that you had a consistent experience

across all of the different services. And that's what this new AWS Command
Line Interface provides.

So, getting set up with the new CLI
is very straightforward. I'm going to cover the installation
and configuration process here.
We support all of the major platforms. So, Windows, Mac, Linux.

And on Windows, you have an MSI installer
available for you. So, you download the MSI, run through the steps,

and we'll set up the appropriate
environment variables so you just have an AWS command available for you.

We also provide a bundled installer. So, a bundled installer has all the
dependencies you need to install the CLI.

Now, by default, it will go in your
home directory. There are command line options that
allow you to change where to install it or whether you
want to create a symlink

to somewhere that's on your path - and we'll look at an example of this

of the CLI. You might have to use sudo depending
on how you have pip set up,

So, that's installation. For configuration, probably the most
important part is how you manage your credentials.

on an EC2 instance
